value.name: Schoolchild Definition & Meaning - Merriam-Webster
value.snippet: — Karl Vick, Time, 25 Oct. 2022 As a schoolchild, Inna lived with her mother in a brutalist high-rise in Saltivka, a neighborhood dominated by such behemoths. — Ed Caesar, The New Yorker, 20 June 2022 Last September, Russian President Vladimir Putin was given a history lesson from a schoolchild.

value.name: SCHOOLCHILD | English meaning - Cambridge Dictionary
value.snippet: Meaning of schoolchild in English. schoolchild. noun [ C ] uk / ˈskuːl.tʃaɪld / us / ˈskuːl.tʃaɪld / plural schoolchildren (informal schoolkid, uk / ˈskuːl.kɪd / us / ˈskuːl.kɪd /) A2. a child who goes to school: We just sat there giggling like naughty schoolchildren. Synonym. pupil.

value.name: schoolchild - Oxford Advanced Learner's Dictionary
value.snippet: student a person who is studying in a school, especially an older child: Students are required to be in school by 8.30. Any high school student could tell you the answer. pupil (British English) a person who is being taught, especially a child in a school: The school has over 850 pupils.

value.name: schoolchild - Wiktionary
value.snippet: schoolchild (plural schoolchildren) A young person attending school or of an age to attend school . 1909 , Archibald Marshall [pseudonym; Arthur Hammond Marshall], “A Court Ball”, in The Squire’s Daughter , New York, N.Y.: Dodd, Mead and Company , published 1919, OCLC 491297620 , page 9 :

value.name: Schoolchild - definition of schoolchild by The Free Dictionary
value.snippet: school 1. ( skuːl) noun. 1. a place for teaching especially children. She goes to the school; He's not at university – he's still at school; (American) He's still in school. escuela, colegio. 2. the pupils of a school. The behaviour of this school in public is sometimes not very good. escuela.

value.name: Schoolchild's Self-esteem as a Factor Influencing Motivation to Learn
value.snippet: feeling. A schoolchild feeling worthless, as he is not accepted by teachers or contemporaries, is tending to avoid learning, his needs are not satisfied. However, a schoolchild who feels esteem, importance, appreciation is tend to be interested in learning, rather than another who feels alienated and unacknowledged. _____
